Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohns disease, ulcerative colitis)
Anemia (iron deficiency can cause both leukocytosis and fatigue leading to presyncope)
Mastocytosis (rare, but can cause all these symptoms)
Drug-induced (e.g., ACE inhibitors for angioedema, sulfonylureas for hypoglycemia)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Autoimmune disorder (e.g., Sjögrens syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Adverse effects of medications (e.g., bisphosphonates for osteoporosis)
Kawasaki disease (in adults, this is rare)
justification: Common cause of abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and potentially syncope and dehydration.}, {diagnosis: Dehydration
justification: Can be caused by diarrhea and lead to syncope, hypoxia, and dyspnea.}, {diagnosis: Pulmonary embolism (PE)
justification: Can cause hypoxia, dyspnea, and syncope. Abdominal symptoms less common but possible.}, {diagnosis: Acute coronary syndrome (ACS)
justification: Severe cases can cause syncope, dyspnea, and hypoxia. Abdominal pain possible but less common.}, {diagnosis: Vasovagal syncope
justification: Common cause of syncope, often triggered by pain or stress. Abdominal symptoms could be the trigger.}, {diagnosis: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
justification: Can cause abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and lead to complications like anemia causing hypoxia and dyspnea.}, {diagnosis: Intestinal obstruction
justification: Causes severe abdominal cramps, vomiting, and can lead to dehydration, hypoxia, and shock.}, {diagnosis: Appendicitis

justification: Typically presents with abdominal pain migrating to the right lower quadrant, but can cause nausea, vomiting, and in severe cases, complications leading to syncope and dehydration.}, {diagnosis: Anemia
justification: Can cause hypoxia, dyspnea, and fatigue leading to syncope.  May be related to GI bleeding from some conditions causing other symptoms.}, {diagnosis: Panic disorder
justification: Severe anxiety can cause a variety of physical symptoms including  abdominal pain, diarrhea, shortness of breath, dizziness, and fainting.}
Allergic reaction (e.g., food, medication, insect sting)
Heart problems (e.g., arrhythmia, heart valve problems)
Sepsis (especially in older adults or those with weakened immune systems)
Inner Ear Infection (Labyrinthitis or Vestibular Neuritis)
Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) - Requires urgent medical attention
Vasculitis (e.g., granulomatosis with polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Viral infection (e.g., Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus, HIV)

Vasculitis (e.g., granulomatosis with polyangiitis, microscopic polyangiitis)

Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) with autoimmune hemolytic anemia
Central nervous system infections (e.g., meningitis, encephalitis)
Viral infections (e.g., Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus, HIV)
